dbq_name: Peripheral Nerves Conditions (Not Including Diabetic Sensory-Motor Peripheral Neuropathy)

rating_criteria.description: Peripheral nerve conditions are rated based on degree of paralysis - complete or incomplete

paralysis_types.complete_paralysis: Total loss of function of the nerve

incomplete_paralysis.severe: Marked muscular atrophy, severe sensory disturbances

upper_extremity.description: Nerve root compression in cervical spine

lower_extremity.description: Nerve root compression in lumbar spine

sciatic_nerve_detail.description: Most commonly rated peripheral nerve condition for veterans

levels.criteria: Severe incomplete paralysis with marked muscular atrophy
Complete paralysis - foot dangles and drops, no active movement below knee, weakened or lost knee flexion

key_testing.nerve_conduction_study: Measures speed of electrical signals in nerves
key_testing.importance: Objective testing that supports severity level

moderate: Reduced grip strength or foot strength
severe: May have foot drop or wrist drop
complete: Total functional loss of affected area

radiculopathy_special_note.description: Radiculopathy is extremely common and often missed
radiculopathy_special_note.claim_tip: If you have back or neck conditions, ALWAYS claim radiculopathy as secondary
symptoms: Pain radiating down arm or leg
radiculopathy_special_note.rating_separate: Radiculopathy is rated separately from the spine condition itself

tips_for_veterans: Describe ALL symptoms: numbness, tingling, burning, pain, weakness
Explain which parts of your body are affected
Mention if you drop things or have trouble gripping
Report any foot drop or difficulty walking
Get nerve conduction study/EMG for objective evidence
If you have back/neck problems, CLAIM RADICULOPATHY
Describe how nerve problems affect daily activities and work
Document any muscle wasting or atrophy
Mention if symptoms radiate from spine to extremities
Note which hand is dominant (affects ratings for upper extremity)
common_mistakes: Not claiming radiculopathy secondary to spine conditions
Failing to describe severity of symptoms
Forgetting to mention dominant hand for arm conditions

bilateral_consideration.description: Both sides can be rated separately
bilateral_consideration.example: Bilateral radiculopathy from back condition = separate rating for each leg
bilateral_consideration.tip: Always claim both sides if both are affected

important_notes: Major (dominant) arm gets higher ratings than minor arm
Radiculopathy should ALWAYS be claimed if you have spine conditions
Each affected nerve can be rated separately
EMG/nerve conduction studies provide objective evidence
Bilateral conditions get separate ratings for each side
Peripheral neuropathy from diabetes uses separate DBQ (Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy)
